revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = TDC A/S | logo = TDC.svg | logo_size = 150px | type = [[Aktieselskab]] | foundation = 1990 | location_city = [[Copenhagen]] | location_country = [[Denmark]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|Pierre Danon ([[Chairman]])|Pernille Erenbjerg ([[President (corporate title)|President]] & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])}} | industry = [[Telecommunications]] | products = [[Landline|Fixed line]] and [[mobile phone|mobile telephony]], [[Internet]], [[digital television]], [[Information technology|IT services]], satellite phone, Web hosting | revenue = [[Danish krone|DKK]] 23.344 billion (2014){{cite web |url=http://annualreport2014.tdc.dk/files/tdc_annual_report_2014.pdf |title=Group Annual Report 2014 |accessdate=20 August 2015 |publisher=TDC}} | operating_income = DKK 3.808 billion (2014) | net_income = DKK 3.228 billion (2014) | assets = DKK 74.4 billion (end 2014) | equity = DKK 18.6 billion (end 2014) | owner = [[Macquarie Group]]
PFA
PKA
[[Arbejdsmarkedets Tillægspension|ATP]] | num_employees = 8,594 ([[full-time equivalent|FTE]], end 2014) | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|tdcgroup.com}} }} [[File:TDC Group May 2017.jpg|thumb|float|TDC, YouSee headquarters in [[Kongens Enghave|Sydhavnen]], Copenhagen.]] '''TDC A/S''' or '''TDC Group''' (formerly '''T'''ele '''D'''anmark '''C'''ommunications) is a Danish telecommunications company dating back to 1879. TDC Group is the largest telecommunications company in [[Denmark]]. The company's headquarters are located in [[Copenhagen]]. TDC Group is the [[parent company]] of several [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]] and brands: Blockbuster, Cirque A/S, Company mobile, Hiper, Dansk Kabel TV, [[Fullrate]], [[Get AS]], NetDesign, TDC Erhverv, [[Telmore]], Unotel, and [[YouSee]]. ==History== On 21 August 1882 [[Carl Frederik Tietgen]] acquired the Copenhagen division of [[International Bell Telephone Company]], an American-owned telephone exchange on Lille Kongensgade in Copenhagen, for DKK 200,000 and founded Kjøbenhavns Telefon Aktieselskab, KTS, later Kjøbenhavns Telefon Aktieselskab, KTAS. In November 1990, the [[Folketing]] passed a law that paved the way for a nationwide Danish telecom. The company was named Tele Danmark and was the parent company for the existing regional companies (KTAS, Jydsk Telefon, Tele Sønderjylland, Fyns Telefon, and Rigstelefonen).{{cite web|last1=Madsen|first1=Erling|title=Fjernsynets historie|url=http://slks.dk/fileadmin/user_upload/dokumenter/medier/Tv/Generelt/Fjernsynets_historie_Erling_Madsen_BFE.pdf|website=Slots- og Kulturstyrelsen|publisher=Erling Madsen/BFE|accessdate=19 March 2017}}{{cite web|title=TDC A/S|url=http://denstoredanske.dk/Erhverv,_karriere_og_ledelse/Erhvervsliv/Erhvervsvirksomheder/TDC_AS|publisher=Den Store Danske|accessdate=19 March 2017}} In 1995, the regional companies were merged into Tele Danmark, and the first nationwide cable TV company, Tele Danmark Kabel TV was created.{{cite web|title=TDCs historie|url=http://aarsrapport2011.tdc.dk/Menu/Aarsrapport/Om+TDC+Koncernen/Historie/TDC%27s+historie|publisher=TDC|accessdate=19 March 2017}} Five years later, in 2000, Tele Danmark changed its name to TDC.{{cite news|last1=Bertelsen|first1=Jens|title=Tele Danmark ændrer navn til TDC|url=https://www.computerworld.dk/art/69048/tele-danmark-aendrer-navn-til-tdc|accessdate=19 March 2017|publisher=Computerworld|date=14 December 2000}} In January 2000 TDC got a new logo with five ovals in red, yellow, green, turquoise and blue colour. In December 2000 Tele Danmark changed its name to TDC. At the same time it demerged into a parent holding company and a number of subsidiaries with the purpose of increasing customer focus, creating greater transparency and achieving faster time to market for products and services. Over the past decade,{{When|date=October 2012}} TDC developed from a traditional and mainly Danish provider of landline and mobile telephony services into a Danish-based [[Europe]]an provider of communications solutions. [[Deregulation]] of the Danish telecommunications market in 1996 created a highly competitive{{Clarify|reason=vague|date=July 2015}} market. In 2004, the Danish telecommunications market was fully liberalized. TDC was partly [[privatized]] in 1994 and fully privatized in 1998, and at year-end 2004, TDC's shares were held mainly by institutions and retail investors in Denmark, the United Kingdom and the United States.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}} In 2006 TDC adopted a new logo which consists of a cursive rounded-rectangle in blue colour. The text "TDC" appears in the rectangle and remind that the letter "D" is cut a little bit. A group of [[private equity]] firms under the banner Nordic Telephone Company (NTC) offered to buy TDC for a price of about 9.1 billion [[Euro]]. Among the group were companies such as [[Blackstone Group|Blackstone]], [[Permira]], [[Apax Partners]] and [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts|KKR]]. The company bought 88% of the shares, but failed to buy more than 90% of the shares and was thus unable to remove the company completely from the Copenhagen Stock Exchange. Also in 2006, TDC pulled out of the UK mobile telephone market, with the closure of their joint venture with [[EasyGroup]], EasyMobile.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}} In 2007, TDC folded its subsidiaries back into the parent company with the exception of TDC Kabel TV, which continued as an independent legal identity.{{cite news|last1=Hemmingsen|first1=Mikkel|title=TDC opsluger sine datterselskaber|url=https://www.computerworld.dk/art/39134/tdc-opsluger-sine-datterselskaber|accessdate=19 March 2017|publisher=Computerworld|date=1 May 2007}} Later in the year, on 1 October 2007, TDC Kabel TV changed its name to YouSee to signal a focus on more than just TV.{{cite news|title=TDC Kabel TV skifter navn|url=http://nyheder.tv2.dk/nyheder/article.php/id-8758693:tdc-kabel-tv-skifter-navn.html|accessdate=19 March 2017|publisher=TV2|date=26 September 2007}} In 2010 Nordic Telephone Company (NTC) began the process of selling its shares in TDC on the Copenhagen Stock Exchange, initially reducing its 88 percent holding of the company to less than 60 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-09/tdc-declines-after-share-offer-price-is-announced-at-51-kroner.html|title=Bloomberg Business|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=29 July 2015}} In 2012 TDC had a total revenue of 26 billion DKK, and employed around 9,000 people in [[Denmark]]. In 2014 TDC purchased the Norwegian telecommunications firm [[Get AS]] for 12.5 billion [[Danish krone|DKK]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/15/deals-day-idUSL3N0RG30L20140915|title=Deals of the day- Mergers and acquisitions|work=Reuters|accessdate=29 July 2015}} In 2016 TDC purchased Danish IT- and telecom provider Cirque A/S for an unspecified amount. On 1 July 2016 the TDC consumer business was merged with YouSee, migrating the entire TDC customer base of IPTV, broadband and mobile consumers to YouSee.{{cite news|last1=Breinstrup|first1=Thomas|title=Presset TDC bliver til YouSee i Danmark|url=http://www.business.dk/digital/presset-tdc-bliver-til-yousee-i-danmark|accessdate=20 March 2017|date=27 January 2016}} The mobile phone network continues to use the 'TDC' name, as its built by TDC Group instead of YouSee.{{cite news|title=Nyt navn: TDC er blevet til YouSee|url=http://meremobil.dk/2016/06/tdc-er-nu-yousee/|accessdate=20 March 2017|date=27 June 2016}} TDC Group and [[Modern Times Group]] announced on 1 February 2018 a plan for TDC Group to buy MTG Nordics to create a converged business with a new name and brand.{{cite news|last1=Briel|first1=Robert|title=TDC buys MTG Nordics to form converged business|url=https://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2018/02/01/tdc-buys-mtg-nordics-to-form-converged-business/|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Broadband TV News|date=1 February 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Hummelmose|first1=Jens E.|title=Fusion: Ny underholdningskæmpe med YouSee, Viasat, TV3 og Viaplay|url=http://www.recordere.dk/2018/02/fusion-ny-underholdningskaempe-med-yousee-viasat-tv3-og-viaplay/|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Rec.dk|date=1 February 2018}} A week later, a takeover bid from the Australian infrastructure group [[Macquarie Group|Macquarie]] and three Danish pension funds; PFA, PKA and [[Arbejdsmarkedets Tillægspension|ATP]] was leaked to the public, which TDC had rejected.{{cite news|title=Afvist TDC-bud med til at løfte aktieværdi med fem milliarder|url=https://www.business.dk/oekonomi/afvist-tdc-bud-med-til-at-loefte-aktievaerdi-med-fem-milliarder|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Berlingske|date=8 February 2018}} The consortium clarified that the proposed MTG merger was not part of their strategy.{{cite news|last1=Madsen|first1=Thomas Nygaard|title=Konsortium har ikke haft MTG-fusion som en del af planen for TDC-opkøb|url=https://mediawatch.dk/Medienyt/TV/article10290122.ece|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=MediaWatch|date=8 February 2018}} In February the consortium launched an improved take-over offer, which TDC Group now recommended.{{cite news|last1=Briel|first1=Robert|title=TDC recommends new takeover offer|url=https://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2018/02/13/tdc-recommends-new-takeover-offer/|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Broadband TV News|date=13 February 2018}} The proposed MTG merger was called off.{{cite news|last1=Hummelmose|first1=Jens E|title=TDC dropper opkøb af MTG|url=http://www.recordere.dk/2018/02/tdc-dropper-opkoeb-mtg/|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Rec.dk|date=12 February 2018}} The consortium got EU approval for their takeover bid on 28 March 2018.{{cite news|title=Opkøbsønske godkendt: Vejen er banet for TDC-salg|url=https://www.business.dk/digital/opkoebsoenske-godkendt-vejen-er-banet-for-tdc-salg|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Berlingske|date=28 March 2018}} In early April, the consortium announced they had acquired more than 90% of the total shares of TDC Group, making a [[Listing (finance)#Delisting|delisting]] possible.{{cite news|title=Nye ejere klar til at afnotere TDC|url=https://www.business.dk/digital/nye-ejere-klar-til-at-afnotere-tdc|accessdate=9 April 2018|agency=Berlingske|date=9 April 2018}} ==References== ==External links== * {{official website|tdcgroup.com}} {{OMX Copenhagen 20 companies}} {{CATV Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tdc A S}} [[Category:Telecommunications companies of Denmark]] [[Category:Television in Denmark]] [[Category:Private equity portfolio companies]] [[Category:Mobile phone companies of Denmark]] [[Category:Companies based in Copenhagen]] [[Category:Danish companies established in 1990]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Denmark]] [[Category:Danish brands]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox comic book title | title = The Complete Peanuts | image = Completepeanutsvol15052.jpg | imagesize = | caption = The cover to the first volume | schedule = biannual | format = Hardcover, softcover | limited = | ongoing = | 1shot = | genre = | publisher = [[Fantagraphics Books]] | date = | startmo = | startyr = 2004 | endmo = | endyr = 2016 | issues = 26 | main_char_team = [[Snoopy]], [[Woodstock (Peanuts)|Woodstock]], [[Charlie Brown]], [[Sally Brown]], [[Franklin (Peanuts)|Franklin]], [[Lucy van Pelt]], [[Linus van Pelt]], [[Peppermint Patty]] | writers = [[Charles M. Schulz]] | artists = [[Charles M. Schulz]] | pencillers = | inkers = | letterers = | colorists = | editors = [[Gary Groth]] | creative_team_month = | creative_team_year = | creators = [[Charles M. Schulz]] | TPB = | ISBN = | subcat = | altcat = | sort = Complete Peanuts, The | addpubcat# = | nonUS = n }} '''''The Complete Peanuts''''' is a series of books containing the entire run of [[Charles M. Schulz]]'s long-running newspaper comic strip ''[[Peanuts]]''. The series was published at a rate of two volumes per year, each containing two years of strips (except for the first volume which includes 1950–1952). Slipcased sets of two volumes are also available. The series comprises a total of 26 volumes,{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/591072081.html?dids=591072081:591072081&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=MAR+28%2C+2004&author=Tom+Beer&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=You're+High+Art%2C+Charlie+Brown&pqatl=google|title=You're High Art, Charlie Brown|work=The Washington Post article by Tom Beer}} including a bonus book with sketches, interviews, and other extra material. These hardcover books were first published between 2004–2016. Later ''Fantagraphics Books'' also began publishing the series in a softcover format. A companion series titled ''Peanuts Every Sunday'', collecting only the Sunday strips of the ''Peanuts'' series, was launched by Fantagraphics in 2013 and is scheduled to run until 2022. Schulz began to discuss an anthology of his work with [[Fantagraphics Books]] in 1997. The idea of a complete compendium of all published ''Peanuts'' strips was long resisted by Schulz; he did not want some early strips reprinted as he felt they were not as good as the ones he drew later in his career.{{Cite news|url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/books/2001857267_peanuts15.html|title=Seattle's Fatagraphics Books will release 'The Complete Peanuts'|last=McKinnon|first=Heather|date=2004-02-15|work=|access-date=2018-10-10}} Approximately 2,000 of the 17,897 strips had never appeared in a previous U.S. collection. The first book in the series was published in April 2004 and topped the ''[[New York Times Best Seller List]]''. ==Volumes== Besides Schulz's work, each book contains an introduction by an influential individual (often with a connection to Schulz), an index of themes and characters, additional art by designer [[Seth (cartoonist)|Seth]] (all of which is directly based on a specific ''Peanuts'' panel), and a biography of Schulz written by series editor [[Gary Groth]]. In addition, the first volume contains an interview with Schulz conducted by Groth and an extended biography.{{cite web|url=http://www.snoopy.com/comics/peanuts/news/news_042005.html|title=The Official Peanuts Website – News|work=The Official Peanuts Website Announcement}} Sunday panels, which originally appeared in color, are presented in black and white in the series (a decision approved by Schulz's widow, Jean Schulz). The hardcover volumes measure {{convert|8.5|in|mm}} × {{convert|7|in|mm}} while the softcover volumes are {{convert|8.25|in|mm}} × {{convert|6.5|in|mm}}. All the characters on the covers (and their styles) match the time period each volume represents. Volume 25, covering the years 1999 and 2000, also includes the complete run of Schulz's 1947–50 strip ''[[Li'l Folks]]''. This precursor includes early versions of Charlie Brown and Snoopy. A 26th and final volume was announced in 2016 which includes hundreds of miscellaneous sketches, designs, short stories, and covers drawn by Schulz. {|class="wikitable" |- !#!!Title!!ISBN!!Release date!!Cover art!!Spine art!!Introduction!!Page count |- |1||''The Complete Peanuts: 1950 to 1952''||{{ISBNT|1-56097-589-X}}||May 17, 2004||[[Charlie Brown]]||[[Shermy]]||[[Garrison Keillor]]||346 |- |2||''The Complete Peanuts: 1953 to 1954''||{{ISBNT|1-56097-614-4}}||October 17, 2004||[[Lucy van Pelt]]||[[Charlotte Braun]]||[[Walter Cronkite]]||344 |- |3||''The Complete Peanuts: 1955 to 1956''||{{ISBNT|1-56097-647-0}}||April 17, 2005||[[Pig-Pen]]||[[Patty (Peanuts)|Patty]]||[[Matt Groening]]||344 |- |4||''The Complete Peanuts: 1957 to 1958''||{{ISBNT|1-56097-670-5}}||October 17, 2005||[[Snoopy]]||[[Violet Gray]]||[[Jonathan Franzen]]||314 |- |5||''The Complete Peanuts: 1959 to 1960''||{{ISBNT|1-56097-671-3}}||May 17, 2006||[[Patty (Peanuts)|Patty]]||[[Schroeder (Peanuts)|Schroeder]]||[[Whoopi Goldberg]] (US edition)

''New York Times'', March 6, 2016. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/07/business/media/obama-pays-tribute-to-charlie-brown-snoopy-and-the-peanuts-gang.html?_r=0 Obama Pays Tribute to Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the 'Peanuts' Gang]". |- |26||''The Complete Peanuts: Comics and Stories''||{{ISBNT|1-60699-957-5}}||November 22, 2016||[[Charlie Brown]]|| [[Rerun van Pelt]]||[[Jean Schulz]]||344 |} ===Boxed sets=== All of the volumes are also being released in boxed sets of two, housed in a specially designed slipcase.{{cite web|title=About the Complete Peanuts Project|url=http://www.fantagraphics.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=136|accessdate=January 21, 2013}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Title ! ISBN ! Release date ! Center character |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1950 to 1954'' | {{ISBNT|1-56097-632-2}} |October 17, 2004 | [[Charlie Brown]] (Volume 1 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1955 to 1958'' | {{ISBNT|1-56097-687-X}} |October 17, 2005 | [[Snoopy]] (Volume 4 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1959 to 1962'' | {{ISBNT|1-56097-774-4}} |November 17, 2006 | [[Lucy van Pelt]] |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1963 to 1966'' | {{ISBNT|1-56097-868-6}} |August 29, 2007 | [[Linus van Pelt]] (Volume 7 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1967 to 1970'' | {{ISBNT|1-56097-948-8}} |October 19, 2008 | [[Snoopy]] (as the World War I Flying Ace) (Volume 10 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1971 to 1974'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-287-2}} |September 8, 2009 | [[Woodstock (Peanuts)|Woodstock]] (Volume 12 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1975 to 1978'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-376-3}} |September 27, 2010 | [[Peppermint Patty]] (Volume 14 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1979 to 1982'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-472-7}} |August 29, 2011 | [[Schroeder (Peanuts)|Schroeder]] |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1983 to 1986'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-573-1}} |September 19, 2012 | [[Spike (Peanuts)|Spike]] (Volume 18 cover) |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1987 to 1990'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-681-9}} |October 18, 2013 | [[Sally Brown]] |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1991 to 1994'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-774-2}} |October 28, 2014 | [[List of minor characters in Peanuts#Woodstock's bird friends|Woodstock's bird friends]] |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1995 to 1998'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-861-7}} |November 9, 2015 | [[Lucy van Pelt]] |- | ''The Complete Peanuts: 1999 to 2000 and Comics and Stories'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-958-3}} |November 22, 2016 | [[Charlie Brown]] |} ===''Peanuts Every Sunday''=== ''Peanuts Every Sunday'' is a series featuring the ''[[Peanuts]]'' Sunday strips in full color. These books, unlike the ''Complete Peanuts'' series, are scheduled to be released one every year, in ten volumes covering half a decade each (except the first book, 1952–55). Slip-cased sets of two are also available. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Title ! ISBN ! Release date ! Character(s) in focus ! Introduction ! Pages |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1952 to 1955'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-692-4}} | December 2013 | [[Charlie Brown]] | [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] | 288 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1956 to 1960'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-794-7}} | November 2014 | [[Lucy van Pelt]] | [[Chuck Klosterman]] | 272 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1961 to 1965'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-872-2}} | November 2015 | [[Charlie Brown]] and [[Snoopy]] | [[Luc Sante]] | 288 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1966 to 1970'' | {{ISBNT|1-60699-968-0}} | November 2016 | [[Lucy van Pelt]] and [[Snoopy]] | [[Max Apple]] | 288 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1971 to 1975'' | {{ISBNT|1-68396-063-7}} | November 2017 | [[Snoopy]] and [[Woodstock (Peanuts)|Woodstock]] | [[Alexander Theroux]] | 288 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1976 to 1980'' | {{ISBNT|1-68396-141-2}} | December 2018 | [[Pig-Pen]] and [[Peppermint Patty]] | | 288 |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1981 to 1985'' | | 2019 | | | |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1986 to 1990'' | | 2020 | | | |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1991 to 1995'' | | 2021 | | | |- | ''Peanuts Every Sunday: 1996 to 2000'' | | 2022 | | | |} Both the complete series and the Sunday collections are being published in hardback and paperback form, with different covers and supplemental artwork. ==Recognition== ''The Complete Peanuts'' have won several awards including: '''Eisner Awards''' *2005 - "Best Archival Collection/Project" *2005 - "Best Publication Design" (Seth) *2007 - "Best Archival Collection/Project - Strips" '''Harvey Awards''' *2005 - "Special Award for Excellence in Presentation" *2005 - "Best Domestic Reprint Project" *2007 - "Best Domestic Reprint Project" *2008 - "Best Domestic Reprint Project" *2009 - "Best Domestic Reprint Project" ==International editions== All international editions retain the artwork, layout, and format of the original American version (though some of the German volumes feature the original introductions, such as those by [[Matt Groening]] and [[Whoopi Goldberg]], while others feature new ones by Germans such as [[Robert Gernhardt]]). {{As of |January 2017}}, the following have been printed: * [[Canongate Books]] started publication of a UK edition of the series in October 2007, with all volumes published; Volume 5 features a different introduction from the US edition, by [[Russell T. Davies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.canongate.tv/search?q=Complete+Peanuts|title=Complete Peanuts on Canongate}} * [[Carlsen Comics]] began publication of a German edition of ''The Complete Peanuts'' in October 2006, under the title ''Peanuts Werkausgabe''—21 have been released.{{cite web|title=Peanuts Werkausgabe|url = http://www.carlsen.de/web/comic/serie?id=40163|language=German| accessdate = January 21, 2013}} * The Portuguese release of ''Peanuts – Obra Completa'' by [[Edições Afrontamento]] published the first two volumes in 2006, with the sixth released in 2011.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} There is no schedule for the publication of the next volumes.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} * [[Dargaud]] started publishing ''The Complete Peanuts'' in France, under the title ''Snoopy – Intégrales'', in November 2005;{{cite web|title=Snoopy – Intégrales – Editions Dargaud|url = http://www.dargaud.com/snoopy-integrales|language=French|accessdate = January 21, 2013}} later volumes were re-titled ''Snoopy et les Peanuts''. As of 2013, 17 volumes have been published. * In Poland, [[Nasza Księgarnia]] began publishing the collected edition in 2008, under the title ''Fistaszki zebrane'', with 19 volumes released so far. * In Spain, [[Planeta DeAgostini]] is the publisher of ''Snoopy y Carlitos'', with 18 volumes published as of 2013.{{cite web|title=Snoopy y Carlitos|url = http://www.planetadelibros.com/serie-snoopy-y-carlitos-626.html|language=Spanish| accessdate = January 21, 2013}} * In Brazil, [[L&PM Editores]] started publication in November 2009, under the title ''Peanuts Completo''.{{cite web|title=Charles M. Schulz|url=http://www.lpm.com.br/site/default.asp?TroncoID=805134&SecaoID=948848&SubsecaoID=0&Template=../livros/layout_autor.asp&AutorID=637477|language=Portuguese|accessdate=January 21, 2013}} Eight volumes have been released so far. * In Italy, [[Panini Comics]] started publication in April 2005, maintaining the original title ''The Complete Peanuts''. All volumes have been released. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{sisterlinks|display=''The Complete Peanuts''|d=Q3986390|n=no|v=no|voy=no|mw=no|m=no|species=no|wikt=no|c=no|s=no|b=Annotations of The Complete Peanuts|q=Peanuts}} *{{Official website|http://www.fantagraphics.com/series/the-complete-peanuts/}} {{Peanuts}} {{Fantagraphics archive collections}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Complete Peanuts, The}} [[Category:Peanuts (comic strip)]] [[Category:American comic strips]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2004]] [[Category:Eisner Award winners]] [[Category:Harvey Award winners]] [[Category:Fantagraphics Books titles]]

revision.text:
{{about|the comic book series|plants called "desert peach"|Prunus andersonii|and|Santalum acuminatum}}
'''''The Desert Peach''''' is a [[comic book]] created by [[Donna Barr]], chronicling the adventures of the [[eponymous]] protagonist, [[Erwin Rommel|Erwin "The Desert Fox" Rommel]]'s fictitious [[homosexual]] younger brother, [[Oberst]] '''Manfred Pfirsich Marie Rommel''' (1900–1990), nicknamed the "Desert Peach". Early issues of the comic focused on the Peach's command of a misfit unit of the [[Afrika Korps]] from 1940 to 1943; subsequent issues have explored the pre- and post-war lives of Pfirsich ([[German language|German]] for "[[Peach]]") and his supporting cast.
==Publication history== ''The Desert Peach'' was first published in 1988, by Thoughts and Images, later by MU Press/AEON, and still later by A Fine Line. 32 issues were released throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, and subsequently re-released in eight collected volumes; as well, a Desert Peach [[musical theatre|musical]] was produced in 1992, and ''Bread and Swans'', a Desert Peach [[novel]], was released in 2005. With the exception of the musical, all Desert Peach material has been created entirely by Barr.
Barr took ''Peach'' to the [[Modern Tales]] [[webcomics]] collective, where she explored Pfirsich's [[afterlife]]: wracked with guilt for having failed to save enough people from the [[Holocaust]], he sentenced himself to [[Hell]]. The website ceased operations in 2012 and the comics were removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcj.com/one-of-those-things/|title=One of Those Things - The Comics Journal|publisher=}}</ref>
==Inspiration== Barr has said that she was inspired to create the character while working in the file office of the University of Washington, which was being painted a "horrible half-pink, half-tan color." Searching for a color name, she stumbled upon "desert peach", and was immediately inspired by the pun upon "The Desert Fox," the name given to Field Marshal [[Erwin Rommel]] during [[World War II]] . According to his biographers, [[Erwin Rommel]] had a youngest brother, named Manfred, who died in infancy—Barr said she only developed a personality who the universe had prematurely discarded.
==Supporting cast==
The Desert Peach commanded the 469th [[Halftrack]], Gravedigging and Support Unit of the Afrika Korps: a catch-all for misfits, mavericks, and otherwise peculiar soldiers who, for whatever reason, were not suitable for service in the German Army but nonetheless were enlisted. In the words of their medical officer (a [[psychiatrist]] assigned to the 469th because his specialty was considered a "[[Deutsche Physik|Jewish science]]"), it was a unit composed "entirely of stray puppies".
The 469th was based on an escarpment by the sea. Pfirsich was of the opinion that a commander should not merely lead his troops but protect them, and arranged with local [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] commanders that there would be no fighting in that area (although newcomers did not always accept this ''[[modus vivendi]]'').
Throughout the series, Barr focused on many characters; the following list includes some of the most prominent.
*[[Obergefreiter]] '''Udo Schmidt''': Pfirsich's [[orderly]] and [[aide-de-camp]]. Scruffy, dirty, ill-tempered, dark-skinned, secretly Jewish, and with a habit of using pages from ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' as [[rolling paper]]s, Schmidt was the 469th's only card-carrying member of the [[Nazi Party]]. He claimed that his reason for joining was that he had been very young and a desperate Party recruiter had bought him beer. *[[Leutnant]] '''Kjars Dagobert Winzig''': the 469th's self-appointed [[Political commissar|political officer]]. A concert pianist in civilian life, the blond, blue-eyed Winzig was an enthusiastic, [[armband]]-wearing supporter of Hitler and Nazism. However, he was not actually a party member, since (as he shamefacedly explained) "party members have to pay dues". *[[Oberleutnant]] '''Rosen Kavalier''': ace [[Luftwaffe]] [[Aviator|pilot]], and the Peach's [[gay marriage|fiancé]]. A cheerful adventurer, bold and brash, Rosen (whose real name, thanks to his British father, was '''Melvin Gonville Ramsbottom''') once got Pfirsich drunk enough to have heterosexual sex for the first time, claiming that he should experience it at least once. This encounter led to the birth of Pfirsich's son. *[[Obergefreiter]] '''Heinrich Dobermann''': [[munitions]] expert. As the result of a training accident on a [[minefield]], Dobermann was [[brain damage|brain-damaged]], mildly insane, and addicted to several [[painkiller]]s and [[psychotropic]] medications. As well, he adopted a live [[Tellermine 42]] as a pet, naming it "Fridl". * '''Kristof Falbe''': the 469's mute radio operator. Never speaks, just taps the radio microphone to communicate. Always seen holding a small stuffed dinosaur.
==Bibliography==
* Thoughts and Images: **The Desert Peach #1: Who is This Man? **The Desert Peach #2: The Bar Fight **The Desert Peach #3: A Day At The Beach **The Desert Peach #4: Is There A Nazi In The House? **The Desert Peach #5: Flight Of Fancy **The Desert Peach #6: A Day Like Any Other **The Desert Peach #7: Spoiled Fruit **The Desert Peach #8: Dressing Down **The Desert Peach #9: Scourge Of Love **The Desert Peach #10: Two-Timers **The Desert Peach #11: Straight and Narrow **The Desert Peach #12: Child Of The World **The Desert Peach #13: Nobody **The Desert Peach #14: Surprise, Surprise **The Desert Peach #15: The Triangle Trade **The Desert Peach #16: Plight Of The Phoenix **The Desert Peach #17: Culture Shock **The Desert Peach #18: Musical Program **The Desert Peach #19: Self-Propelled Target **The Desert Peach #20: Fever Dreams **The Desert Peach #21: The Good Uncle **The Desert Peach #22: Lady Luck **The Desert Peach #23: Visions **The Desert Peach #24: Ups And Downs **The Desert Peach #25: Beautiful **The Desert Peach Collection: Beginnings (issues 1 - 3) **The Desert Peach Collection: Politics, Pilots and Puppies (issues 4 - 6) **The Desert Peach Collection: Foreign Relations (issues 7 - 9) **The Desert Peach Collection: Baby Games (issues 10 - 12) **The Desert Peach Collection: Belief Systems (issues 13 - 15) **The Desert Peach Collection: Marriage and Mayhem (issues 16, 17, 19) **Ersatz Peach **Peach Slices (first edition - sold out) * A Fine Line Press (available at mupress till #30) **The Desert Peach #26: Miki **The Desert Peach #27: New And Different **The Desert Peach #28: Tongue **The Desert Peach #29: Out Of The East **The Desert Peach #30: Headaches **The Desert Peach #31: Pithed **The Desert Peach #32: Keeper **Peach Slices (second edition, with additional artwork and Desert Peach #25) *Seven Peaches contains the first seven Desert Peach issues *Bread and Swans, the Desert Peach Novel * [http://www.robotcomics.net/2009/07/robot-comics-launches-amazon-kindle/ Robot Comics has announced that it will re-release Desert Peach titles] on the [[Amazon Kindle]].

{{About||the actual number|23 (number)|another film by a similar name|23 (film)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = The Number 23 | image = Number23.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Joel Schumacher]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Beau Flynn]] * [[Tripp Vinson]] }} | writer = Fernley Phillips | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Jim Carrey]] * [[Virginia Madsen]] * [[Logan Lerman]] * [[Danny Huston]] }} | music = [[Harry Gregson-Williams]] | cinematography = [[Matthew Libatique]] | editing = [[Mark Stevens (film editor)|Mark Stevens]] | studio = {{plainlist| * Contrafilm<ref name=afi>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/members//catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=64411|title=The Number 23|work=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref> * Firm Films<ref name=afi/> }} | distributor = [[New Line Cinema]]<ref name=afi/> | released = {{Film date|2007|02|23}} | runtime = 98 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 97:52--><ref>{{cite web|title=''THE NUMBER 23'' (15)|url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/number-23-2007-1|work=[[Entertainment Film Distributors]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=February 8, 2007|accessdate=August 1, 2014}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $30 million<ref name="BOM" >{{mojo title|number23|The Number 23}}</ref> | gross = $77.6 million<ref name="BOM" /> }} '''''The Number 23''''' is a 2007 American [[psychological horror]] [[Thriller film|thriller]] film written by Fernley Phillips and directed by [[Joel Schumacher]]. [[Jim Carrey]] stars as a man who becomes obsessed with the [[23 enigma]] once he reads about it in a strange book that seemingly mirrors his own life. The film was released in the United States on February 23, 2007. This is the second film to pair Schumacher and Carrey, the first being ''[[Batman Forever]]''. The film grossed $77.6 million and has an approval rating of 8% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]].
==Plot== Walter Sparrow is an [[animal control officer]] married to Agatha; they have a son, Robin. At a bookstore, Agatha begins looking at a book titled ''The Number 23'' written by Topsy Kretts. She later gives Walter the book as a birthday present. Walter starts reading the book, noticing odd similarities between himself and the main character, a detective who refers to himself as "[[Fingerling (character)|Fingerling]]." Mirroring the detective, Walter becomes obsessed with the [[23 enigma]], the idea that all incidents and events are directly connected to the number 23, or to some number connected to 23. When he tries to warn Agatha about the number, she tells him he is crazy.
Walter's obsession leads him to believe that the book has secret insights into his own life. When he reads that Fingerling murders his girlfriend, Walter begins having dreams about murdering Agatha. Agatha refers him to her friend, Isaac French, who suggests Walter find the book's author if he wants answers. Walter's search leads him to discover the murder of Laura Tollins. Now believing the book to be a veiled confession, Walter searches for her killer.
Evidence found at a psychiatric hospital reveals Walter in fact is Topsy Kretts, having written the book as a way to rid himself of the guilt he felt over murdering Tollins. He was never suspected of the crime, and a man named Kyle Flinch was convicted and imprisoned instead. Walter had dated Tollins 13 years earlier, but she left him for Flinch. Walter stabbed Tollins to death in a jealous rage and left the scene of the crime, moments before Flinch arrived and touched the knife, implicating himself in the murder. Wracked with guilt, Walter decided to kill himself and began writing a suicide note, but found that he could not stop writing; the note ultimately became the book. He survived his suicide attempt, but the resulting head trauma left him with amnesia.
Fearing he will hurt his family, he leaves home and moves to the same hotel in which he had attempted suicide. Agatha finds Walter at the hotel and assures him that he is no longer the person he was when he wrote the book. He insists that he is a killer and tells Agatha to leave before he kills her, too. He leaves the hotel and runs into the street, where he nearly allows himself to be run over by a bus. Walter steps out of the way at the last minute when he realizes his son is watching. Walter turns himself in to the police and awaits sentencing, having been told that the judge will likely go easy on him. A funeral procession takes place in front of Tollins' grave, where it is implied her body has finally been laid to rest, as Flinch observes, a free man.
==Cast== * [[Jim Carrey]] as Walter Sparrow/Fingerling * [[Paul Butcher (actor)|Paul Butcher]] as Young Walter Sparrow/Fingerling * [[Virginia Madsen]] as Agatha Pink-Sparrow/Fabrizia * [[Logan Lerman]] as Robin Sparrow * [[Danny Huston]] as Isaac French/Dr. Miles Phoenix * [[Rhona Mitra]] as Laura Tollins * [[Bud Cort]] (''uncredited'') as Dr. Leary * Chris Lajoie as Benton * [[Mark Pellegrino]] as Kyle Flinch * [[Lynn Collins]] as Suicide Blonde/Mrs. Dobkins/Young Fingerling's Mother * [[Michelle Arthur]] as Sybil * [[Ed Lauter]] as Father Sebastian * [[Corey Stoll]] as Sergeant Burns
==Reception== The film has an approval rating of 8% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 189 reviews; the average rating is 3.5. The site's consensus reads: "Jim Carrey has been sharp in a number of non-comedic roles, but this lurid, overheated, and self-serious potboiler is not one of them. ''The Number 23'' is clumsy, unengaging, and mostly confusing."<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_number_23/ The Number 23], rottentomatoes.com, accessed March 25, 2007.</ref> Of the few critics who liked the film, [[Richard Roeper]] and critic George Pennachio of [[KABC-TV]] in [[Los Angeles]] stand out, as they gave the film a "2 thumbs up" rating on the television show ''[[At the Movies with Ebert & Roeper|Ebert & Roeper]]'' (Pennachio was standing in for [[Roger Ebert]] due to Ebert's illness).<ref>''Ebert & Roeper'', air date February 24, 2007.</ref>
However, [[Michael Phillips (theatre critic)|Michael Phillips]], filling in for Ebert on the Worst of 2007 show (aired January 12, 2008) put ''The Number 23'' at No. 7 in his list of the worst (Roeper did not include it in his list). [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' declared the film the year's worst [[star vehicle]] on his list of the Worst Movies of 2007,<ref>[[Travers, Peter]], (December 19, 2007) [https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/17686508/peter_travers_best_and_worst_movies_of_2007/15 "Peter Travers' Best and Worst Movies of 2007"] ''Rolling Stone''. Retrieved 2007-12-20</ref> while Colm Andrew of the ''[[Manx Independent]]'' said the film "delivers a rambling, confusing narrative with only a few stylistic elements thrown in".<ref>[http://www.iomtoday.co.im/reviews?articleid=2221070 Review by Colm Andrew] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201082034/http://www.iomtoday.co.im/reviews?articleid=2221070 |date=February 1, 2009 }}, IOM Today</ref>
The film was nominated for two [[2007 Teen Choice Awards|Teens Choice Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfscope.com/2007/08/fox-tvs-teen-choice-awards-recognize-genre-winners/|title=Fox TV’s Teen Choice Awards Recognize Genre Winners|last=Strock|first=Ian Randal|work=[[SFScope]]|date=2007-08-27|accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref> For his performance, Carrey was nominated for the [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actor]] at the [[28th Golden Raspberry Awards]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsok.com/article/3195199|title=Razzie nominations for worst in film announced|author=<!-- Staff -->|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=2008-01-21|accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref> but lost to [[Eddie Murphy]] for ''[[Norbit]]''.
===Box office=== On its opening weekend, ''The Number 23'' took in $14,602,867, coming in behind ''[[Ghost Rider (2007 film)|Ghost Rider]]''{{'}}s second weekend.<ref name=":0">{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2007&wknd=08&p=.htm | title=Weekend Box Office Results for February 23-25, 2007 | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | date=February 26, 2007 | accessdate=August 1, 2014}}</ref> After five weeks of release, the film grossed $35,193,167 at the domestic box office and $42,373,648 overseas, for a worldwide total of $77,566,815.<ref name="BOM" />
==Home media== The film was released on Region 1 [[DVD]] on July 24, 2007; the release contains both the theatrical version and an extended version, which runs an additional four minutes. Special features include [[deleted scene]]s, such as a much more abstract alternate opening and an alternate ending that gives a few more details about Walter's prison sentence and hints at the possibility that the son could be subject to the same obsessions as his father. The disc also includes interviews with mathematicians, psychologists, and [[Numerology|numerologists]]. The DVD shows the film over a set of 23 chapters. As of August 24, 2007, ''The Number 23'' has generated $27.7 million from DVD rental grosses.{{fact|date=September 2015}} This is the last DVD under the [[Infinifilm]] library
==See also== {{Portal|Film}} * [[23 (film)|''23'' (film)]] * [[Retrograde amnesia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0481369}} * {{tcmdb title|641987}} * {{mojo title|number23}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|the_number_23}}
{{Joel Schumacher}}

page.title: The Rage of the Stage Players

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2015}}
'''The Rage of the Stage Players''' is an alternative, fringe theatre group based in south western [[Pennsylvania]], USA.<ref name="Goldberg2013">{{cite book|author=Alex Goldberg|title=Turn the Page|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CCiVEaktFqEC&pg=PA4|year=2013|publisher=Original Works Publishing|pages=4–|id=GGKEY:S3RF2RE2FN9}}</ref> The group specializes in staging plays with mature themes.<ref>[http://www.utimes.pitt.edu/?p=19499 "Greg Lightner: staffer by day, monster master by night"]. ''University Times''</ref><ref>Newby, Collette. [http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/rage-of-the-stages-dorothy-in-oz/Content?oid=1739229 "Rage of the Stage's Dorothy in Oz"], ''Pittsburgh City Paper'', 26 March 2014.</ref>
==History==
The Rage of the Stage Players was founded in 2001 by playwright James Michael Shoberg and wife Carrie L. Shoberg.<ref>[http://triblive.com/x/valleyindependent/news/s_125928.html#axzz2pCG2I87 "Rage of the Stage Players new to Valley"] Jan. 19, 2015 ''The Valley Independent'', March 27, 2003</ref> The company has produced original plays based on familiar children's stories,<ref>[http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Best-of-the-Burgh-Blogs/After-Dark/March-2013/Rage-Against-the-Reboot/#.VL5H0Xt0elo "Rage Against the Reboot"]. ''Pittsburgh Magazine''. SEAN COLLIER March 21, 2013</ref> legends and fairy tales, such as "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland",<ref>{{cite web|last=Hayes|first=John|title=Stage Review: Urban adaptation puts Alice into a darker Wonderland|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/ae/theater-dance/stage-review-urban-adaptation-puts-alice-into-a-darker-wonderland-450226/?print=1|publisher=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=September 13, 2006}}</ref> "Dracula",<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/2007/09/12/Stage-Review-New-Dracula-delights/stories/200709120191 "Stage Review: New 'Dracula' delights"]. ''Pittsburgh Post=Gazette'', September 12, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.pittnews.com/news/article_420e8fd5-ca97-532d-9433-0c886795a578.html?mode=jqm "Rage of the Stage brings Drac back"]. ''The Pitt News'' JESSICA BOPP | Sep 13, 2007</ref> "Dorothy in Oz",<ref>{{cite web|last=Pilecki|first=Michelle|title=Dorothy in Oz|url=http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/dorothy-in-oz/Content?oid=1342546|publisher=Pittsburgh City Paper|accessdate=September 24, 2009}}</ref> "The Picture of Dorian Gray"<ref>[http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/rage-of-the-stages-the-picture-of-dorian-gray/Content?oid=1703183 "Rage of the Stage's The Picture of Dorian Gray "]. Pittsburgh City Paper''.</ref> and a stage adaptation of [[The Butcher Brothers]] movie, [[The Hamiltons]].
In 2006, J.P. Patrick was awarded Best Actor for his performance in "The Hideous Face of Love", a play produced by The Rage of the Stage Players as part of the Pittsburgh New Works Festival.<ref>[http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2006/10/24/Most-ers-tops-New-Works-awards/stories/200610240145 "'Most-ers!' tops New Works awards"]. October 24, 2006 By Christopher Rawson ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''.</ref>
== References ==
