{{Infobox recurring event | name = VRTO Virtual & Augmented Reality World Conference & Expo | native_name = | logo = VRTO logo.jpg | logo_size = 150px | logo_caption = | frequency = Annually | location = Toronto, Canada | first = | last = 2015 | participants = | organised = | people = [[Keram Malicki-Sanchez]] | website = {{URL|conference.virtualreality.to}} }} Started in 2015, as a [[Virtual Reality]] [[Meetup (website)|Meetup Group]] in Toronto, VRTO launched the '''VRTO Virtual & Augmented Reality World Conference & Expo''' in June 2016 - an international exhibition and professional conference exploring arts, culture and science through immersive technologies. Its inaugural year - held at the Mattamy Centre<ref>[http://www.mattamyathleticcentre.ca/events/detail/vrto-world-virtual-augmented-reality-conference-expo-2016 Mattamy Athletic Centre Box Office]</ref> (better known as [[Maple Leaf Gardens]] in [[Toronto]], [[Canada]] - featured keynotes from [[University of Toronto]] Professor [[Steve Mann]], Hollywood film director [[Brett Leonard]] - director of [[The Lawnmower Man (film)|The Lawnmower Man]], Chief Digital Officer Ana Serrano of the [[Canadian Film Centre]] and Phil Lelyveld of [[University of Southern California|USC]].
Founded and directed by producer, [[futurist]], musician and Hollywood actor [[Keram Malicki-Sanchez]],<ref>[http://virtualreality.to/ VRTO official site]</ref> the opening year featured a keynote, [[town hall]] and discussion panel around creating a Code of [[Ethics]] for Humanistic Augmentation<ref>[http://www.kurzweilai.net/code-of-ethics-on-human-augmentation-the-three-laws Kurzweil AI] Code of Ethics on Human Augmentation: the three ‘Laws’</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=VRTO Spearheads Code of Ethics on Human Augmentation|url=https://www.vrfocus.com/2016/07/vrto-spearheads-code-of-ethics-on-human-augmentation/|website=VRFocus|accessdate=20 March 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Toronto Arts and Events|url=http://torontoartsandevents.com/index.php/events/viewArticle/135|website=torontoartsandevents.com|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> VRTO Spearheads Code of Ethics on Human Augmentation also known as the [[HACode]] or [[The Toronto Code]].<ref>[http://uploadvr.com/lawnmower-man-brett-leonard-steve-mann-vrto/ ‘Lawnmower Man’ Director Brett Leonard and Meta’s Steve Mann Keynote VRTO Conference]</ref>
== VRTO 2016 == The conference, in its inaugural year welcomed 800<ref>{{cite web|title=VRTO Virtual & Augmented Reality World Conference & Expo 2016|url=http://fashionecstasy.com/vrto-virtual-augmented-reality-world-conference-expo-2016/|website=fashionecstasy.com|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> attendees and 64 speakers from Toronto, Montreal<ref>[https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/toronto-vr-expo-explores-canadian-095900010.html Yahoo Finance] Toronto VR Expo explores a Canadian-wide collaboration with Montreal technology leaders</ref> and Los Angeles, and featured over 20 companies working in the development of virtual reality, [[augmented reality]] and [[mixed reality]] in addition to training sessions dedicated to the creation of [[360 video]], game development, [[photogrammetry]] and [[WebVR]]. The conference featured a preview of the [[FIVARS Festival of International Virtual & Augmented Reality Stories]].
The conference featured a workshop titled The Hacker's Guide to the Metaverse that taught programming [[WebVR]] using the [[JanusVR]] [[open source]] platform.<ref>{{cite web|title=FIVARS at VRTO Virtual & Augmented Reality World Conference & Expo!|url=http://fivars.net/news/fivars-vrto-virtual-augmented-reality-world-conference-expo/|website=FIVARS|accessdate=20 March 2017|date=20 May 2016}}</ref>
== VRTO 2017 == The largest conference dedicated on virtual and augmented reality in Canada, the sophomore year featured 100 speakers and 60 installations<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/charliefink/2017/07/08/vr-toronto-hand-made-and-well-done/#28802778212d FORBES: "VR Toronto Hand Made and Well Done"]</ref>. The second year of the VRTO Conference & Expo in 2017 was staged at the [[Rogers Communications Centre]] on the [[Ryerson University]] campus in downtown Toronto June 24th-26th with the theme of "Giants" based on the quote by [[Sir Isaac Newton]]: "“If I have seen further than others, it is by standing upon the shoulders of Giants.”
Keynote speakers included Stanford neuroscientist Professor Walter Greenleaf, PhD, Graham Smith, [[David_A._Smith_(computer_scientist) |David A. Smith]], Dr. [[Sara_Diamond_(college_president) | Sara Diamond]] - President of [[OCAD_University | OCAD University]], [[Moses_Znaimer | Moses Znaimer]], Charlie Fink<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/charliefink/2017/07/08/vr-toronto-hand-made-and-well-done]</ref>, Dr. Karan Singh and James McCrae - founders of [[JanusVR]] and additional live interviews with [[Steve_Mann | Steve Mann]], and Tim Merel among others.<ref>[https://virtualrealitytimes.com/2017/06/15/toronto-is-ready-to-host-vrto-2017-a-major-vr-ar-world-conference-expo/], Toronto is ready to Host VRTO 2017 –A Major VR & AR World Conference & Expo</ref>
Several panels, under the banner of "Super Sessions" featured leaders in the field of Virtual & Augmented Reality, health sciences (Dr. Lora Appel, Dr. Tom Overly, Dr. Stephane Bouchard), "Out-of-Home" entertainment (James Jensen of [[The_Void_(virtual_reality) | THE VOID]], Eyal Kleiner of [[IMAX]], Ed Callway of [[Advanced_Micro_Devices | AMD]]).
The show was also the launchpad for various products and initiatives including the [[Canadian Film Centre]]'s Pulse on VR "living ecosystem" report on the Virtual Reality industry, the [[Webmoti]] camera that mitigates social anxiety for children with [[autism]] who wish to participate in the classroom, and the [[Somato Cherry]]<ref>[Toronto is ready to Host VRTO 2017 – A Major VR & AR World Conference & Expo]</ref> [[haptic technology|haptic]] wireless virtual reality controller.
Themed pavilions were co-curated between Malicki-Sanchez and specialists in their respective fields including Dr. Maria Karam (somatosensory pavilion), Ian Kelso ([[Augmented Reality]] conference track, Isaac Rayment (Augmented Reality "ARt Gallery") that featured early Augmented Reality artists Zenka, Daniel Leighton, Alex Mayhew, Dan Goldman, among others.
== VRTO 2018 == VRTO 2018 shifted its lens to [[psychedelia]], [[Western_esotericism | esoterica]], philosophy and phenomenology and how they relate to experiential design, [[blockchain]] and [[Visual Effects]] featuring such speakers as [[Steve_Williams_(animator) | Steve "Spaz" Williams]], [[Philip_Rosedale | Philip Rosedale]], and [[Brett_Leonard | Brett Leonard]], alongside 85 other leaders of the VR industry. In its third year, the event added an extra day of conferences, workshops and training.

[[File:FvfSanJoseBaliuag9734 05.JPG|thumbnail|An [[internet café]] in [[Baliuag]], [[Bulacan]] with posters of [[MMORPG]]s]] '''Video gaming in the Philippines''' is an emerging industry and [[Hobby|pastime]] that includes the production, sale, import/export, and playing of [[video games]]. The Philippine eSports Organization (PeSO) is an eSports entity that is the official Philippine representative to the International eSports Federation (IeSF), which is one of the largest eSports associations in the world. It carries the interests of the Filipino eSports community in the international arena.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esports.inquirer.net/15455/what-is-peso|title=What is PeSO? - Esports by Inquirer.net|date=4 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
==Demographics== [[File:Time Crisis 5 Arcade Cabinet front entrance.JPG|thumb|An arcade video game in [[Makati]].]] NIKO Media Research projected the number of PC Gamers to rise from 21 million in 2012 to 28.72 million in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/323776/pc-online-gamer-numbers-philippines/|title=SEA mobile gamers by age and gender 2016 - Statistic|website=Statista|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
==Game development industry== [[File:Tong-Its_Game_2003_Screenshot.jpg|thumb|[[Tong-its]] game released in November 2003 by Rico Zuñiga]] The Philippines is a minor player regarding the game development industry. In 2011, it was reported that the local industry only has a 0.02% market share of the $90 billion global industry. The majority of the game development industry is focused on [[outsourcing]] to foreign companies rather than creation of local content.<ref name=presentfuture>{{cite news|title=Game on: the present and future of game development in the Philippines|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/242660/scitech/technology/game-on-the-present-and-future-of-game-development-in-the-philippines|accessdate=15 November 2015|publisher=GMA News|date=28 December 2011}}</ref> According to the Game Developers Association of the Philippines (GDAP), there are about 4,000 professionals representing about 60 companies involved in the game development industry as of 2013. The Philippines' primary competitors in this field are [[China]], [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Vietnam]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Game development industry booming in PHL, says GDAP|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/290814/scitech/technology/game-development-industry-booming-in-phl-says-gdap|accessdate=15 November 2015|publisher=GMA News|date=17 January 2013}}</ref>
The first Filipino-developed commercial computer game was ''[[Anito: Defend a Land Enraged]]'' which was released in November 2003.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Valderrama|first1=Michael|title=The Philippines in video games|url=http://archive.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/opinion/2014/09/19/valderram-philippines-video-games-366386|accessdate=15 November 2015|publisher=Sun Star Bacolod|date=19 September 2014}}</ref> 2 months prior to the release of Anito, in September 2003, a free and open source [[Solitaire]] card game named Drac was also released by Rico Zuñiga, which makes Drac the first Filipino-developed computer game and [[Game_engine|game development framework]].<ref name="webarch">{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030927010408/http://drac-cardlib.sourceforge.net|title=Drac - Free SDL Card Game Library|date=27 September 2003|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> Drac was also used to create another card game based on the rules of the popular Filipino game, [[Tong-its]] which was released on November 2003.<ref name="pex">{{cite web|url=https://www.gamedev.net/forums/topic/191135-announcing-stig-version-008a/|title=Announcing Stig! version 0.0.8a|website=GameDev.net|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="github">{{cite web|url=https://github.com/ricoz/tongits|title=ricoz/tongits|website=GitHub|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
In 2016 the French video game development company [[Ubisoft]] announced plans to establish a subsidiary in the country, which opened on March 28, 2016 in [[Santa Rosa, Laguna]] in partnership with [[De La Salle University]].<ref name="Wilson">{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/03/28/ubisoft-philippines-is-the-island-nations-first-major-game-studio/|title=Ubisoft Philippines is the island nation's first major game studio|last=Wilson|first=Jason|date=28 March 2016|work=VentureBeat|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Morris">{{cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/03/28/ubisoft-doubles-down-in-southeast-asia/|title=Ubisoft Doubles Down in Southeast Asia - Fortune|last=Morris|first=Chris|date=28 March 2016|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Otero">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/29/ubisoft-opens-a-new-studio-in-the-philippines|title=Ubisoft Opens a New Studio in the Philippines - IGN|last=Otero|first=Jose|date=28 March 2016|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref>
The University of The Visayas New School (UVNS) offers esports and game development through their Senior High Arts and Design track.<ref name="inquirer.net">{{cite web|url=http://esports.inquirer.net/18417/philippines-getting-esports-school|title=The Philippines is getting its very own esports school - Esports by Inquirer.net|date=8 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> UVNS offers subjects like game theory, mechanics, strategy, and game awareness. Students can also pick up game design, branding, and shoutcasting as well as entrepreneurship.<ref name="inquirer.net"/>
After the return qualification of two Filipino teams for the world DOTA 2 tournament in 2017, esports backers like Sen. [[Bam Aquino]] see the potential of the online gaming industry to bring honor to the country while creating jobs and ushering in investments.<ref name="philstar.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/06/30/1715053/esports-seen-usher-jobs-businesses-philippines|title=Esports seen to usher in jobs, businesses into Philippines - Philstar.com|website=philstar.com|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
==In eSports== Due to the popularity of video gaming in the Philippines, various outlets have conducted tournaments from local to international levels. In 2016 the Manila Cup held various gaming competitions with participation by local and international players, featuring games such as ''[[Mortal Kombat XL]]'', ''[[BlazBlue Chronophantasma]]'' and ''[[Street Fighter]]''. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/13/street-fighter-manila-cup-esports-philippines|title=A Street Fighter in Manila: how eSports is kicking off in the Philippines|first=Tala|last=Wong|date=13 September 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> Big name conventions such as the [[Asia Pop Comic Convention]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esports.inquirer.net/16033/peso-bring-esports-festival-asia-pop-comic-con|title=PeSO to bring the eSports Festival to Asia Pop Comic Con - Esports by Inquirer.net|date=30 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://esports.inquirer.net/16112/esports-festival-games-announced|title=eSports Festival Games Announced! - Esports by Inquirer.net|date=5 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> and eSports and Gaming Summit hold various video game tournaments as part of their programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rappler.com/technology/features/150490-esgs-2016-lineup-preview|title=5 reasons a gamer shouldn't miss ESGS 2016|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref>
The surging popularity of esports in the Philippines has led to various Filipino teams competing in renowned eSports tournaments worldwide,<ref>http://www.philstar.com/sports/2016/08/10/1612050/pinoy-gamers-oust-team-og-guaranteed-p23.5m-dota-2-tiff</ref> even producing champions over different tournaments.<ref name="philstar.com"/>
In 2017, a national eSports league was established which is called as [[The Nationals (eSports)|The Nationals]].
==Controversies and issues==
===1981 ban on video games=== On November 19, 1981 President [[Ferdinand Marcos]] banned video games in the country through a presidential decree, making the Philippines the first nation to ban video games. The decree was [[Moral panic|a response]] to complaints from parents and educators who alleged that games such as ''[[Space Invaders]]'' and ''[[Asteroids (video game)|Asteroids]]'' were [[Think of the children#Censorship|detrimental]] to youth morals, viewing them as a "destructive social enemy"<ref>{{cite news|title=President Marcos bans video game machines|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/10056192/?terms=marcos+video+games|newspaper=Logansport Pharos-Tribune|date=19 November 1981|page=17|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = February 26, 2015 }} {{Open access}}</ref> and existing "to the detriment of the public interest".<ref name="PD519">{{cite web|url=http://source.gosupra.com/docs/provision/78753|title=Presidential Decree No. 519 - Supra Source|accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dillon|first=Roberto|title=The Golden Age of Video Games: The Birth of a Multibillion Dollar Industry|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=1439873232|date=12 April 2011|publisher=CRC Press|location=Page xvii|isbn=1439873232}}</ref> Marcos also decreed the ban of [[pinball]] machines, slot machines, and other similar gaming devices. Filipinos were given two weeks to either destroy their video games and devices or surrender the materials to the police and army. Violators had to pay a fine amounting to about $600 and face 6 months to 1 year of prison. Playing video games in the country went underground. The ban was effectively lifted following the [[1986 People Power Revolution]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Marcos Bans Video Games|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/world/marcos-bans-video-games.html|accessdate=15 November 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=19 November 1981}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Philippine President Bans Videogames|url=http://www.historychannel.com.au/classroom/day-in-history/950/philippine-president-bans-videogames|accessdate=15 November 2015|work=History Channel}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dillon|first1=Roberto|title=The Golden Age of Video Games: The Birth of a Multibillion Dollar Industry|date=2011|publisher=A K Peters/CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=1439873232|page=xvii|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pq6-X1fTm2oC&lpg=PR17&ots=oRwSwuTw71&dq=marcos%20bans%20video%20games&pg=PR17#v=onepage&q=marcos%20bans%20video%20games&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2015|chapter=Timeline}}</ref>
===Localized ban on ''Defense of the Ancients''=== While no video games have been banned nationwide since 1986, at least one title, ''[[Defense of the Ancients]]'', has been banned at a [[barangay]] in [[Dasmariñas, Cavite]] following complaints of [[Juvenile delinquency|delinquency]] and two murder incidents involving youths in the area resulting from brawls related to the game.<ref name="DOTABan">{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/413042/news/regions/dota-banned-in-internet-shops-in-cavite-village|title=DOTA banned in internet shops in Cavite village|date=21 January 2015|work=[[GMA News]]|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref>
===Copyright infringement=== [[Copyright infringement|Unauthorized distribution]] of video games is a complex issue in the Philippines. Despite legislation against copyright violation, enforcement and cultural factors remain an obstacle in the country. Bootleg video games, along with [[warez]], contribute to the [[underground economy]] of the country where video gaming is a popular form of entertainment among Filipino families. The inability of many Filipino families to afford video game software and hardware at legitimate prices leads them to turn to unlicensed goods. The [[Optical Media Board]] in cooperation with the police enforces intellectual rights law in the country.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vitale|first1=Jennifer Kim|title=Video Game Piracy in the Philippines: A Narrowly Tailored Analysis of the Video Game Industry & Subculture|journal=Pace International Law Review|date=January 2010|volume=22|issue=1 Winter 2010|url=http://digitalcommons.pace.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1032&context=pilr|accessdate=15 November 2015}}</ref>
